docs.lead_paragraph: The nation's unemployment rate fell to a seven-year low of 5.1 percent in August and hourly earnings posted their second healthy increase in three months, the Labor Department reported today. The job-market data, which offered the first broad view of the nation's economic performance last month, were strong enough to inspire the Clinton Administration to further boasting about its economic record. But they were not so powerful as to immediately worry securities markets that have become increasingly nervous that the pace of growth is too fast.

headline.main: JOBLESS RATE FELL TO 5.1% IN AUGUST, LOWEST IN 7 YEARS

docs.abstract: Labor Dept reports that nation's unemployment rate fell to seven-year low of 5.1 percent in Aug and hourly earnings posted their second healthy increase in three months; says employers added 250,000 workers to their payrolls in Aug; Pres Clinton hails figures as showing that economy is 'on the right track'; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: In the latest big settlement by a clinical laboratory company of Federal Medicare fraud charges, SmithKline Beecham P.L.C. expects to pay the Government about $300 million this year, without admitting any wrongdoing. Analysts said the Laboratory Corporation of America also expects to settle similar charges by the end of the year. SmithKline, based in London, had said repeatedly earlier this year that it was setting aside $400 million to settle both the Medicare charges, which involve billings for blood tests that were deemed not medically necessary and, in some cases, may not have been ordered by a physician, and its share of several price discrimination lawsuits that retail pharmacies had brought against drug manufacturers.

headline.main: SmithKline Beecham in Settlement With U.S.

docs.lead_paragraph: James W. Bishop Jr. does not like insurance agents. So when he decided he needed more life insurance, he did not call his local agent; in fact, he did not pick up the phone at all. Instead, he just went up to his bedroom and turned on his computer. In a few minutes on the Internet, he got estimates from five companies on how much a $500,000 term policy would cost. He conferred with his wife, thought about it for a few days, then went back to his machine and ordered the insurance through the World Wide Web, the graphic component of the Internet.

headline.main: Internet Sales Offer an Insurance Alternative
headline.kicker: When the Agent of Change Is a Click of The Mouse

docs.abstract: Advent of cybersales may force insurance companies to rethink traditional role of salesmen; so far, number of Internet shoppers is small, but relatively young people, who are already comfortable with Internet as resource for information or retail sales, are starting to turn to it for insurance needs as well; ranks of such shoppers are expected to swell; Internet insurance is now spreading beyond relatively simple term life policies; some companies have begun offering auto and individual health insurance, as well as specialized policies; many industry executives are resisting, citing possible breaches in security if networks were widely used for policy sales; those selling on Internet say they use complex encoding systems to protect buyers and that chances of losing material in cyberspace are remote; photo; drawings (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton will soon appoint a Federal advisory commission to recommend ways of protecting consumers against changes in the health care industry that threaten the quality of care, Administration officials said today. The study will lay a foundation for health policy initiatives and legislative proposals if Mr. Clinton wins a second term.

headline.main: Clinton to Name Health-Care Panel, With Eye to Second Term

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton reportedly will appoint Federal advisory commission to recommend ways of protecting consumers against changes in health care industry that threaten quality of care; study will lay foundation for health policy initiatives and legislative proposals if Clinton wins second term (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: RESTAURANTS are turning up the gas. An early Labor Day has only shortened this elusive summer, and as the calendar rushes toward fall, new dining spots are about to open. While architects, designers and construction crews add finishing touches to dining rooms and chefs fine-tune their menus, restaurant managers face the toughest task of all: forging a disparate group of men and women, many of whom have never before worked together, into a cohesive, effective service staff.

headline.main: Going Beyond 'Hi, My Name is Pat'
headline.kicker: Restaurants Are Trying to Grow Up

docs.abstract: Owners of new restaurants opening this fall in New York scramble to recruit good staff (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Three years ago, when medical costs were soaring and a new President was flailing about for a solution, a prediction that the rate of increase in health-care costs could be cut to well below 10 percent annually would have been greeted with smirks. But this week came further confirmation of radical change. A survey of 4,000 physicians found that their incomes were falling. That reversal arises largely from the explosive growth of managed-care plans, which have squeezed out layers of excessive spending. Meanwhile, insurance premiums in many regions like northern California are either level or falling -- an unimaginable prospect when President Clinton locked 500 ''experts'' in a room and told them to dream up a new health-care system.
docs.abstract: Editorial lauds trend among physicians toward cost containment in provision of medical services; says it may make it possible to extend health insurance coverage to uninsured, beginning with children (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: International A3-15 SECOND U.S. STRIKE AGAINST IRAQ The United States launched a second attack against Iraq, just hours after President Clinton vowed to make the Iraqi leader pay for aggression against the Kurds in northern Iraq. A1 FINISHING THE PERSIAN GULF WAR News analysis: Facing limited and messy options after the earlier war against Iraq ended without overthrowing its leader, President Clinton is fighting the war George Bush never finished. A1 DOLE, IN SHIFT, OFFERS SUPPORT After assessments that he would be open to criticism, Bob Dole backed away from his earlier comments about the action in Iraq, saying he offered his support for American forces in the Middle East. A1 PRESSURE WITHOUT TAKING SIDES American officials said the decision to hit military installations in the southern part of Iraq was an effort to punish Baghdad while avoiding taking sides in the dispute between rival Kurdish groups. A9 The world made it clear the United States was on its own in Iraq. A10 For Kurds, a history of defeat and betrayal. A9 IN INDIA, OUT BUT NOT DOWN The former Prime Minister of India, who lost his office and was linked to corruption scandals, has given the impression recently that he, not his successor, is the real power in India. A3 RISING DEATH TOLL FOR CHECHNYA Russia's national security adviser said the death toll for the war in Chechnya was probably at 80,000, more than twice earlier estimates, but some human rights groups said the figures were up to date. A3 UNDERMINING BOSNIA ELECTIONS The growing number of complaints about abuses related to the Bosnian election may cause the vote to be so disputed that it detracts from Bosnian stability, rather than cementing it as was intended. A14 Guerrillas broke off peace talks with the Mexican Government. A7 More charges for Canada's military in the scandal over Somalia. A6 Beijing Journal: In a puzzling era, a tough message to the West. A4 National A16-19, B8-B9 MALL PLANS CURFEW The Mall of America, the nation's largest, has been troubled by rowdy teen-agers. So the mall plans to require young shoppers to have chaperones on weekends, a policy that will be closely watched by other shopping centers. A1 A SWING TOWARD CLINTON In an enclave of independent voters, in Moreno County, Calif., sentiment appears to be tilting toward President Clinton and away from the Republicans. A1 WELFARE WORRIES ON THE BORDER Hidalgo County in Texas, one of the poorest in the nation, expects to be hit the hardest by the welfare overhaul. A1 A DROUGHT EASES It's still not enough, but recent rains in parched areas in Texas and Oklahoma are welcome. A16 POLITICALLY CORRECT CREEK? Ordered to drop the word ''squaw'' from place names because some consider it derogatory, a Minnesota county fights back with names signaling resistance. A16 BOMB SUSPECT FIGHTS BACK Lawyers for Richard A. Jewell, the security guard who is a suspect in Olympic bombing, is asking a court to make public the reasons his property was searched. A19jewel RACE IN MASSACHUSETTS Representative Peter G. Torkildsen is a Republican, but he is emphasizing his independence as he seeks re-election. B9 Education B7 As school choice ferments, options are distilling into clear favorites. A Colorado's student's protest of video sparks evolution debate. docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: ''As Insurers Cut Fees, Doctors Shift to Elective Procedures'' (front page, Aug. 24) points out an economic trend: physicians in many specialties are moving to cosmetic surgery to increase or maintain income. However, there are other, more significant trends associated with cosmetic surgery. For example, when physicians specialize in one area like facial plastic surgery, it leads to increased expertise and better results.

headline.main: Cosmetic Surgery Benefits From More Doctors

docs.abstract: Dr Wayne F Larrabee Jr letter disputes Aug 24 article on reduction in fees by insurers which has forced doctors to shift to elective procedures (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The uses of lobbying and the impact of print and broadcast journalism are not uninspected subjects, but tonight's first installment of ''The People and the Power Game'' uses case histories to good effect to bring home why they have become so troubling in recent years. Taking on the press, that old newspaperman Hedrick Smith focuses on the Gennifer Flowers episode to demonstrate how an account of President Clinton's extracurricular affinities made it from a supermarket tabloid to the most respectable network news programs. Peter Jennings confesses that ABC's ''World News Tonight'' was swept along by events.

headline.main: A Further Freedom: To Catch Up With Trash News

docs.abstract: Walter Goodman reviews The People and The Power Game, written and created by Hedrick Smith, host; show is part of PBS Democracy Project; photo of Smith (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After more than a decade caring for patients who might not survive to middle age, Dr. Howard A. Grossman of New York has begun to imagine a day when gay men would need his services as a geriatrician. That was what he aspired to be at the outset of his career. But his plans, like those of so many in the community he wanted to serve, were overtaken by the AIDS epidemic. Dr. Grossman found himself specializing in a disease that did not even have a name when his medical education began in 1979.

headline.main: For AIDS Doctors, a Needed Tonic

docs.abstract: Many doctors who treat large numbers of AIDS patients believe they are witnessing single greatest advance in 15-year battle against the disease, with introduction of new combination drug therapies, including medications known as protease inhibitors, that effectively fight HIV virus; results to date have been so dramatically hopeful that they were cited by Pres Clinton in his speech at Democratic National Convention; photo (M)
